So said  Vladimir R. Bossicard  on  12/6/2002 --------------------

>> This has to do with understanding the role of programmer tests as
>> opposed to customer tests. I have some fuzzy ideas in this
direction,
>> but nothing to make a paper possible yet. The bottom line is
>> understanding the importance of blazing fast programmer tests and of
>> separating PTs from CTs.
>
>What I did for Xindice (XML Database) is to separate the tests (unit,
>integration and stress).  The unit tests run all the time but the
>integration
>tests run less often.

This is an excellent solution.

>The problem is that Xindice provides several drivers (xml-rpc and
embed) to
>access the database.  To test the xml-rpc driver, you have to generate
the
>xindice.war file, copy it into your Tomcat's (e.g.) webapps directory
and
>reload it.  If you do this each time you make a tiny modification it's
>quite
>painful (and not everyone has a Tomcat server running).  So it was
natural
>to
>separate the tests according to their complexity.

Absolutely. I encourage doing this until you figure out another way to
do it. This may never happen.

<snip />
>Another question: how would you handle a test that is supposed to pass
but
>that
> currently fails because of a problem you can't fix?
